degree_multipliers.rationale: Activists and campaign volunteers are natural social hubs — they intentionally expand their networks to mobilize others and attend frequent meetings and events.
Managers and professionals maintain large professional networks through work, industry events, and LinkedIn-style connections.
Self-employed individuals rely on broad personal networks for clients and referrals, making them well-connected hubs.
Highly extraverted individuals actively seek out social connections and maintain more relationships.
Regular voters are more civically engaged and tend to participate in community organizations, expanding their networks.
People who attend religious services more than weekly are deeply embedded in their congregation community, a major source of real-world social ties.
Heavy social media users accumulate more online connections and are exposed to more potential social ties.

edge_type_rules.name: household_member
edge_type_rules.description: Members of the same household — spouses, domestic partners, or cohabitating adults — share the closest possible bond.

edge_type_rules.name: congregation_member
edge_type_rules.condition: a_religious_affiliation == b_religious_affiliation and a_religious_attendance != "Never" and b_religious_attendance != "Never" and a_state == b_state
edge_type_rules.description: People who attend the same type of religious institution in the same state — a major source of tight community ties in American life.

edge_type_rules.name: political_community
edge_type_rules.condition: a_political_affiliation == b_political_affiliation and a_civic_engagement == b_civic_engagement and a_state == b_state
edge_type_rules.description: People who share political affiliation and civic engagement patterns in the same state — e.g., party members, campaign volunteers, local activists.

edge_type_rules.name: neighborhood_acquaintance
edge_type_rules.description: People living in the same state and same urban/rural context — neighbors, local community members, and people who frequent the same local spaces.

edge_type_rules.name: online_community
edge_type_rules.description: People who use the same social media platform and consume similarly-leaning news — forming online communities and echo chambers.

edge_type_rules.name: weak_tie
edge_type_rules.description: Weak ties between people of similar educational background and race/ethnicity — reflecting broad social sorting patterns in American society.

influence_factors.description: Higher education correlates with perceived credibility and information authority. Graduate-degree holders are more likely to influence others' opinions on policy issues.

influence_factors.levels: {"Rarely/Never votes": 1, "Votes sometimes": 2, "Votes regularly": 3, "Actively volunteers or campaigns": 4}
influence_factors.description: Active campaigners and volunteers are opinion leaders by design — they explicitly attempt to persuade others and are trusted sources within political communities.
Higher income individuals tend to carry more social capital and are perceived as more authoritative on economic policy questions.
People with higher institutional trust tend to defer to established sources and are more predictable opinion holders, making their views more stable and influential in moderate circles.
